2025-05-03 20:14:44,442 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Central Bank of the Philippines\' monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: - the highlights of the discussions of the 18 november 2004 monetary board meeting were approved by the monetary board during its meeting held on 16 december 2004. namely: the deputy governor for the banking services sector, research and treasury, the deputy governor for supervision and examination sector, the assistant governor, in-charge of research and the director of the treasury department.\n                "}]

and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the rates of expansion picked up in china, russia, and australia, but slowed in the us, japan, the uk, and india.\n                "}]

"justification": "The sentence discusses economic growth rates in various countries but does not mention monetary policy or its implications."

programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the members of the monetary board noted that the philippine economy posted a better-than-expected real gdp growth for 2002, driven mainly by the upturn in consumption spending and the recovery in exports.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence mentions a better-than-expected real GDP growth, driven by consumption spending and export recovery, indicating a strong economy that may not require contractionary monetary policy."
}

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: - the cumulative 200-basis-point policy rate cut of the bsp from 18 december 2008 to 9 july 2009 appeared to have been passed on by banks to their borrowers.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence mentions a cumulative 200-basis-point policy rate cut, which indicates a reduction in interest rates, signaling expansionary monetary policy."
}

\\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: commodities remain, as considerable demand from emerging economies is expected to continue, while supply responses to rising relative prices have been slow to adjust.\n                "}]

"justification": "The sentence discusses commodities and supply and demand, but does not mention monetary policy or its effects, making it irrelevant to the stance feature."

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: this brings the year-to-date net adjustment in the prices of gasoline products to p8.00 for unleaded gasoline, - p1.69 for diesel, - p3.49 for kerosene, and p2.26 for lpg.\n                "}]

recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: net domestic assets (nda), meanwhile, decreased anew by 9.3 percent in april following a decline of 3.5 percent in march.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:15:28,212 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "A decrease in net domestic assets indicates an increase in the money supply, which is a sign of monetary easing."
}

Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: - on 16 june 2016, bank indonesia (bi) decided to reduce its (12-month) bi rate and respectively, to help strengthen the country’s growth momentum.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The reduction of the BI rate indicates a monetary easing to stimulate the country's growth momentum."
}

recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in the fourth quarter of 2008, gross capital formation contracted, and if sustained, economic growth over the medium term could further slow down.\n                "}]

"justification": "The contraction of gross capital formation and potential slowdown of economic growth suggest a need for monetary easing to stimulate the economy."

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence only reports on the current state of global financial markets and growth momentum without indicating any change in monetary policy or stance."

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the price of brent crude oil for july 2010 deliveries declined to us$74.43 per barrel on its month-ago level of us$86.63 per barrel.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The decline in Brent crude oil price indicates a potential decrease in production costs and inflation, which may lead to monetary easing."
}

50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: this was partly offset by the continued expansion in credit to the private sector, which rose by 5.8 percent from 5.2 percent, as lending to entities other than financial corporations was sustained during the month.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates an expansion in credit to the private sector, which suggests an increase in the money supply, signaling a dovish stance."
}

\\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, a number of risks remain, notably the expected slower growth trajectory of the us economy, a disorderly unwinding of global imbalances, and a potential increase in financial market volatility.\n                "}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence mentions risks that could lead to higher inflation and financial instability, which may require contractionary monetary policy to mitigate."
}

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: headline inflation increased in junejuly driven mainly by rising transport costs such as, higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\n                "}]

}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: - the overall balance of risks to the inflation outlook remain tilted to the downside for 2020 to disruptive covid-19 pandemic due to social distancing measures and recurring waves of infection is the primary downside risk to inflation.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:16:09,322 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates a downside risk to inflation, which suggests that inflation is likely to be lower than expected, creating room for monetary easing."
}

in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: - early indications point to near-record world production of cereals for - bank lending rates declined by 224.0 basis points during the period posted for the period 8-12 december 2008, bringing the pass-through rate to 110 percent.\n                "}]

Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy.
