Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: stock market - in september, the market generally succumbed to grave external pressures following the collapse of the lehman brothers, the sale of merrill lynch & co. to bank of america, and the us fed’s takeover of the american international group, inc. (aig).\n                "}]

\\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: ng disbursements for ps, mooe, and ioco grew by 10.7 percent in january-october 2023 following the improved spending performance of government agencies such as the department of public works and highways; department of Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: - efforts to raise infrastructure spending provided a boost to domestic activity.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:16:32,815 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "Increased infrastructure spending is likely to stimulate the economy, indicating a need for monetary easing."
}

stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: continued to be relatively low.\n                "}]

"justification": "The sentence implies a low inflation environment, which may indicate room for monetary easing."

Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: meanwhile, us eia also revised their supply projections given the higher-than-expected supply from russia as the country continued to search for alternative consumers.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:16:47,105 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence discusses US EIA's supply projections and Russia's search for alternative consumers, which is not related to the Central Bank of the Philippines' monetary policy."
}

recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the monetary board also noted that a further easing of the bsp’s monetary policy stance at this time would infuse additional liquidity in the system, which already has ample liquidity.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that easing monetary policy would add to already ample liquidity, implying that the current stance is not accommodative enough."
}

Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: 2025-05-03 20:17:01,187 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Central Bank of the Philippines\' monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: credit extended to the private sector slowed down to 7.2 percent year-on-year from 8.1 percent in the previous month.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:17:01,187 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "Slowing down of credit extended to the private sector indicates a decrease in money supply, which signals a dovish stance."
}

50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: - the monetary board’s decision was based on its assessment that the latest baseline inflation forecasts are within target for 2021 to 2023, although supply-side interventions by the government continue to play a crucial role in keeping inflation within the target range.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:17:06,353 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence indicates that the monetary board's decision is based on inflation forecasts being within target, implying no change in monetary policy."
}

\\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: debt spreads started to ease by mid-july after greece and its creditors agreed on a bailout package and after the chinese government intervened to arrest the stock market rout.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The easing of debt spreads and the intervention of the Chinese government to stabilize the stock market suggest a reduction in market uncertainty, which could lead to a more accommodative monetary policy."
}

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: stock market - the local bourse was at its worst in october.\n                "}]

Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: - mean inflation forecasts from surveys of private sector economists continued to show generally elevated inflation expectations for 2018-2020.\n                "}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "Elevated inflation expectations indicate a potential need for contractionary monetary policy to control inflation."
}

programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the board will also remain watchful of any emerging risk to future inflation to ensure stable prices, which is a precondition to robust and durable economic growth.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence indicates a cautious stance, but does not imply a change in monetary policy, instead emphasizing the importance of price stability for economic growth."
}

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: percent year-on-year to reach p1.49 trillion as of end-november increase in bank lending also represents an improvement from the february 2004 auction, reflecting the negative market sentiment over the credit rating downgrade by moody’s investors service and uncertainties relating to the current political landscape.\n                "}]

}

\\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: as a result, gdp growth accelerated to 1.8 percent in q4 from 0.4 percent in the previous quarter.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide}
